POEMS IN ENGLISH * No.
Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
"THE TIDE RISES, THE TIDE FALLS"
The tide rises, the tide falls.
The twilight darkens, the curlew calls;
Along the sea-sands damp and brawn
The traveller hastens toward the town.
And the tide rises, the tide falls.
Darkness settles on roofs and walls.
But the sea, the sea in the daiidiess calls;
The little waves, with their soft, white hands,
Efface the footprints in the sands,
And the tide rises, the tide falls.
The morning breaks; the steeds in their stalls
Stamp and neigh, as the hostler calls;
The day returns, but nevermore
Returns the traveller to the shore.
And the tide rises, the tide fails.
I* A BRIEF PARAPHRASE
As the sun goes down, a traveller hurries along the shore toward town; night
comes, the tides wahs away the traveller’s footprints; finally the day returns
and the traveller is gone forever*
The careful reader will see that this brief episode is not all that is
being described by Longfellow, but that the poem presents a contrast: nature’s
world, typified by the sea, is eternally renewed. Man’s life on earth is
temporary and of short duration. The poem expresses the constancy of nature
and the fleeting existence of a human being.
